prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Burden on single party

para.paratext: The Panel has repeatedly rejected arguments that focus on the burden, expense or inconvenience that would be sustained by a single party if transfer were ordered. This argument was the “worm's eye view” rejected by the Panel in an early decision.[1] The Panel has consistently followed that decision, favoring instead a “global” view of the litigation and considering the burden, expense, and inconvenience of all parties.[2]

The Panel has also taken a pragmatic view of this question. For example, it has rejected claims of great travel expense or inconvenience by noting that transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings does not require the parties to attend the proceedings in the transferee court and that discovery of the parties can take place in the district where the parties reside.[3] The Panel has also noted that use of lead counsel, liaison counsel, and steering committees can reduce the need for travel and the expense related with it.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385, 386 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See, e.g., In re Federal Election Campaign Act Litigation, 511 F. Supp. 821 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225, 229 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
